item.title: Shoppers spending billions on post-Christmas sales, but small retailers feel forgotten
item.description: Outlet centres around Australia were bustling on Boxing Day, but just down the road, some small retailers were feeling the sting. It's a trend that could shape the future of the Boxing Day sales.

item.title: Donald Bradman's baggy green to go under the hammer
item.description: A baggy green worn by Sir Donald Bradman during the 1947-48 series against India has gone to auction.

item.title: Nick Offerman hopes The Pout-Pout Fish delights tough child critics
item.description: This Australian animation stars an international and local voice cast led by Nick Offerman and Nina Oyama, who can't wait for children to see the film.

item.title: Gold, silver and palladium prices pull back sharply, worrying some economists
item.description: The price of palladium — used in electronics — tumbles from recent highs while the prices of other precious metals, including gold and silver, have also sharply declined in recent days.

item.title: Impact of abbreviated Boxing Day Test stretches far beyond the MCG
item.description: The economic and social impact of the Boxing Day Test reaches far past the pitch and the repercussions of the two-day finish rippled all across Melbourne.

item.title: Russia's claim Ukraine attacked Putin's home 'doesn't make any sense', experts say
item.description: A defence analyst tells the ABC an attack on the Russian President's state residence would be "technically" possible but would not make sense strategically for Ukraine.

item.title: NT Environment Protection Authority orders Santos, Inpex licence conditions review
item.description: The Northern Territory environment regulator will re-examine the licence conditions of major gas facilities in Darwin, after one of its biggest operators admitted to under-reporting potentially toxic emissions at its Ichthys LNG plant on Darwin Harbour.

item.title: Khaleda Zia, Bangladesh's first female prime minister, dead at 80
item.description: Begum Khaleda Zia was leader of the main opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party which was seen as the frontrunner to win the next parliamentary election in February.

item.title: Adelaide public transport, stations and interchanges join list of declared public precincts
item.description: Police have been given expanded powers to search people for weapons on every public bus, train and tram in the Adelaide metropolitan area ahead of New Year Eve's celebrations.

item.title: Here's what we know about the Coral Adventurer, the cruise ship that ran aground in PNG
item.description: The Coral Adventurer was carrying 80 tourists into the remote reaches of Papua New Guinea when it came to an abrupt halt on a reef off the Pacific nation's coast.

item.title: Bizzi Lavelle uncovers the hidden history of Blak burlesque in Australia
item.description: Bizzi Lavelle, a Queer Wakka Wakka and Arrernte writer and burlesque dancer known in the scene as Bizzi Body, is reclaiming the hidden legacy of this art-form one tassel twirl at a time.

item.title: South Korea bans bear bile farming with jail for those who breach the law
item.description: South Korea is one of the few countries that allow farming to extract bile from bears, for traditional medicine or food believed to promote vitality and stamina.

item.title: Christmas cruise ends in chaos as Coral Adventurer passengers return home
item.description: About 80 passengers on the Coral Adventurer are flown home after the cruise ship ran aground on a reef off Papua New Guinea.

item.title: UAE withdraws personnel from Yemen after Saudi Arabia air strikes
item.description: The UAE has denied shipping weapons to Yemeni separatists after Saudi-led forces said they had bombed arms at the port city of Mukalla.

item.title: Today in History, December 31: Vladimir Putin rises to power in Russia
item.description: Vladimir Putin has towered over politics in Russia since ascending to the country's top office, initially as president for eight years, then as prime minister until that pesky thing called the constitution could be altered to allow him to run again.

item.title: Kakadu traditional owner says nature has long warned us about rising sea levels
item.description: In wet season, Jonathan and his family have to drive, boat and drive again if they want to reach town. The remote NT traditional owner says nature has long been warning us about climate change, "but nobody's listening".

item.title: Crowd-funding business campaigns falter, despite demand for tipple
item.description: Brewer Richard Jeffares's Victorian company raised about $2.5 million from 993 investors in a matter of days through a method called crowd-sourced funding, also known as equity crowdfunding.

item.title: Sportsbet pressured key watchdog into 'watering down' enforcement announcement
item.description: Gambling giant Sportsbet pressured the Australian Communications and Media Authority into "watering down" enforcement announcement, the ABC can reveal.

item.title: Human-operated Tokyo robot venture allows housebound people to work
item.description: Ory Yoshifuji's Tokyo business employs housebound individuals to operate robots as waitstaff at a cafe and as personal tour guides in the city.

item.title: What should you do during a violent mass attack?
item.description: The mass shooting in Bondi and other incidents of mass violence around the world have highlighted that violence can strike anywhere. Here are some expert tips on how to escape, hide, and stay safe.

item.title: Denmark becomes first country in world to end letter delivery
item.description: After 401 years, the Danish postal service has ended letter deliveries as the country fully embraces the digital age.

item.title: Robbers steal $52 million from vault of German savings bank
item.description: According to police, the robbers drilled their way into the underground vault room of the savings bank from a parking garage.

item.title: For many South Australians, 2025 could be summarised as the year of searching for answers
item.description: As 2025 draws to a close and we look back at the stories that made headlines, for South Australians the year could be summarised as one where we searched for answers, with little results.

item.title: Mechanic shortage driving Queensland businesses to look overseas for qualified workers
item.description: The automotive repair industry says it is dealing with a major labour and skills shortage, and some mechanics are looking overseas for workers.

item.title: ASX ends 'stressful' year with gold and lithium stocks surging despite Trump's trade war threats
item.description: Several gold, lithium and other mining stocks have seen their share price double, and even triple, in 2025 as Australia's share market has had a much better than expected year despite tariffs, economic uncertainty and Donald Trump's ongoing unpredictability.

item.title: Tatiana Schlossberg, granddaughter of John F Kennedy, dies aged 35
item.description: Tatiana Schlossberg revealed in an essay published in November that she had a rare form of terminal leukaemia.

item.title: Flocks of tourists dubbed the 'koala paparazzi' putting animals at risk in Byron Bay
item.description: Large crowds of tourists gather daily at the bottom of trees home to koalas in Byron Bay, leaving the animals stressed and their habitat trampled.

item.title: Record year for Australian beef exports despite Donald Trump's tariffs
item.description: When Donald Trump enforced a 10 per cent tariff on Australian beef, there were some concerns it would impact trade. But the opposite happened.

item.title: Calls for tighter regulations after Woodside knowingly shed plastic into ocean
item.description: Documents reveal one of Australia's biggest oil and gas companies knowingly shed plastic into the ocean for two months before notifying the offshore regulator.

item.title: Flooding claims a life as deluge cuts north-west Queensland roads, isolates towns
item.description: Police have renewed warnings about driving in floodwaters after a tragedy in Queensland's Gulf Country as the region endures a fourth day of drenching rain.

item.title: What are the new rules in 2026? Here's what's changing from New Year's Day
item.description: New Year's Day brings a host of new laws, regulations and guidelines into effect. Here's a quick breakdown of some of the changes.

item.title: AI technology gives swimming pool lifeguards an extra set of eyes this summer
item.description: An AI system used in 120 public pools across Australia analyses swimmers' movements and sends an alert to a lifeguard's smartwatch if it detects someone in trouble.

item.title: Broken Hill gardeners chop down trees in battle with Queensland fruit fly
item.description: There was no fruit fly to be found in Broken Hill 20 years ago, but now gardeners are facing an uphill battle trying to rid themselves of the pest.

item.title: Calls for national strategy to tackle apprentice hazing and protect workers’ mental health
item.description: TV presenter and former builder Barry Du Bois is lobbying Canberra for change.

item.title: Former Australian Test batsman Damien Martyn in an induced coma with meningitis
item.description: Former Australian Test and limited overs batsman Damien Martyn is in hospital in Queensland in an induced coma after falling ill this week.

item.title: Promise of bumper coffee crop in 2026 fuelled by explosion of white flowers
item.description: Australian coffee growers are hoping for a bumper 2026 season to meet increased demand for homegrown beans following a prolific flowering season.

item.title: Ashes 2025: Alex Hartley responds to criticism for talking about period on BBC commentary
item.description: Alex Hartley says she was stunned by the reaction to her talking about her period during the BBC's radio commentary of the third Ashes Test.

item.title: 'White Australia' flyer letterbox drop in Newcastle sparks police investigation
item.description: NSW Premier Chris Minns said police would "throw the book" at anyone behind flyers distributed to inner-city Newcastle letterboxes.

item.title: Socceroos striker Martin Boyle in injury blow for Hibernian
item.description: Martin Boyle, no stranger to the heartache of missing major tournaments with the Socceroos, was taken off after injuring his hamstring for Hibernian in the Scottish Premiership.

item.title: Australia's top glassmakers are the focus of the exhibition Glass Chrysalis II
item.description: The art of glassblowing was popularised in a recent reality TV series, but these Australian artists are forging their own paths in the creative process of sculpting this tricky medium.

item.title: Sunshine Coast live music venue The Station to shut down as event bookings drop
item.description: The Sunshine Coast's largest live music venue is shutting down, with the owners stating that they need double the number of bookings to stay afloat.

item.title: Driver in hit and run that killed woman on Darwin's Bagot road remains at large
item.description: The search for a hit-and-run driver who allegedly struck and killed a 27-year-old Indigenous woman on one of Darwin's busiest main roads continues into its fifth day.

item.title: Pet owner's warning as dogs fall ill after beach visit amid algal bloom crisis
item.description: Within 20 minutes of leaving an Adelaide beach dogs Lucy and Ella began breathing rapidly and fell "terribly sick", prompting their owner to issue a warning.

item.title: Man drowns and boy missing after boat capsizes at Palm Beach
item.description: Police confirmed one man has drowned and a 14-year-old boy is missing after their boat capsized at Palm Beach on Sydney's Northern Beaches, with a search and rescue helicopter continuing to search the area.

item.title: Felix Auger-Aliassime hopes for deep Australian Open run after career-best year
item.description: After his best year on tour, Canadian star Felix Auger-Aliassime is looking to keep his hot streak running in the United Cup and at the Australian Open.

item.title: Iranian president admits protesters have 'legitimate demands' as inflation fuels unrest
item.description: Protests over soaring prices and a collapsing currency are spreading across Iran, with students joining shopkeepers in calling on the government to take action.

item.title: Wednesday Finance with Dan Ziffer
item.description: News from the world of finance and business. Top stories in text, video and audio. Business video news bulletin. Features and analysis.

item.title: Thailand releases 18 soldiers held since July as part of border conflict ceasefire deal
item.description: The release is a key part of a ceasefire deal struck to bring peace to the border between the two countries.

item.title: Nearly 60 female Japanese MPs lobby for more toilets in the nation's parliament
item.description: There are just two toilets for women near the main hall in Japan's parliament, with nearly 60 MPs calling for changes to the building to match growing female representation.

item.title: Previously secret cabinet documents reveal Howard government tried to mitigate 'homegrown' terrorist threat
item.description: From expectations of a trade union backlash against controversial industrial relations reform, to concerns about "homegrown" extremism in Australia, here are what previously unseen cabinet documents tell us about Australian politics in 2005.

item.title: Today in History, January 1: Evonne Goolagong wins her first Australian Open title
item.description: After an extended break and a shower, Goolagong changed tactics in the deciding set to sail to victory over American Chris Evert back in 1974.

item.title: Interest rate hikes, an AI bubble and other as-yet-unanswerable 2026 problems
item.description: Australia’s top economists talk interest rate hikes and market movements.

item.title: How running helped Darwin entertainer Shalom Kaa overcome substance abuse
item.description: Shalom Kaa used to think running was something other people did. But after a series of events that left him at his lowest, running became a big part of his recovery following years of substance abuse with crystal methamphetamines.

item.title: Countries adopting 'new year's resolutions' with health, economy and internet laws
item.description: From currency changes to cleaner toilets, here's what is changing around the world in the new year.

item.title: What ABC journalists will be closely watching in 2026
item.description: Disruptions to the world trade system courtesy of Donald Trump and a reshaping of historic alliances as multiple wars drag on have set the stage for a precarious year in global affairs.

item.title: Israel banning dozens of aid organisations from operating in Gaza
item.description: The Israeli government says the organisations have not met new requirements, which include recognising Israel as a Jewish and democratic state and banning any so-called "de-legitimisation" of Israel.

item.title: Double stabbing in popular dining strip in Carlton leaves two men in hospital
item.description: Two men were taken to hospital with serious injuries after being stabbed in Carlton shortly before midnight.

item.title: Two people charged after police find explosive devices at a property in Bendigo
item.description: A man and a woman will face court charged with numerous offences, including manufacturing unauthorised explosive devices.

item.title: Unsealed documents from 1995 Queensland Labor government cabinet detail decision-making processes 30 years later
item.description: The cabinet documents were originally sealed in 1995. Today, they shed light on the decision-making processes of the government of the day.

item.title: Floodwaters to linger in north-west Queensland for weeks with heavy rain forecast
item.description: Outback towns remain cut off, and floodwaters are expected to linger in the north-west for weeks. Graziers have started to assess their properties and count stock losses.

item.title: Around the world people celebrate new year and hope 2026 brings peace
item.description: Cities around the world have rung in the new year in spectacular style, with fireworks lighting up famous landmarks from the London Eye to Egypt's pyramids.

item.title: High-dose MDMA warning for revellers attending Sydney's Field Day
item.description: A pill testing trial has been expanded to Sydney's Field Day music festival, but authorities are urging partygoers not to be complacent.

item.title: Brisbane Roar coach Michael Valkanis's send-off sparks half-time clash with Central Coast Mariners
item.description: The fallout from Brisbane Roar's spiteful A-League clash with Central Coast continues, with the Roar "considering all options" after comments from Mariners coach Warren Moon following a send-off for Brisbane coach Michael Valkanis that prompted a half-time confrontation in Gosford.

item.title: Jurassic Park fan fulfils childhood dream of recreating Jeep
item.description: Zakary Weyer's obsession with Jurassic Park drove him to learn different skills to build a replica of the Jeep that appears in the iconic blockbuster.

item.title: The nudists baring it all to address misconceptions about naked beach culture
item.description: Half a century after the first nude beach opened in Australia, these naturists say they are still fighting to keep beaches open and misconceptions at bay.

item.title: Chris Lynn wins Adelaide Strikers' New Year's Eve BBL game against Brisbane Heat
item.description: Former Brisbane star Chris Lynn clobbers the Adelaide Strikers to an easy victory over the Heat in the New Year's Eve Big Bash League clash.

item.title: Handwritten letters among items in the unsealed case file of hanged murderer Jean Lee
item.description: Jean Lee and her two co-accused were executed for murder in 1950. Handwritten letters from the trio are among items publicly available for the first time since their trial captured the nation's attention.

item.title: Four titan arum 'corpse flowers' to bloom in a week at Cairns Botanic Gardens
item.description: Renowned for their size and stench, blooming corpse flowers are a rare occurrence. But to have four flowering in a week is "something of a record".

item.title: Police happy with Victorian NYE revellers despite multiple arrests and illegal fireworks injuries
item.description: Police make 18 arrests and several people are taken to hospital for injuries related to illegal fireworks as Victorians see in the new year.

item.title: Three drown, man and teenage boy missing in multiple coastal emergencies off NSW waters
item.description: A man and two women have died and two people are missing following four separate incidents on Sydney waters over the past 48 hours.

item.title: Rare freshwater Bloomfield River cod surviving amid environmental threats
item.description: The Bloomfield River cod, found in a far north Queensland river catchment, is the world's only tropical freshwater cod, and scientists are working to have it officially protected amid threats from the climate and introduced species.

item.title: Permanent commercial demersal fishing ban begins for large part of WA
item.description: From today, commercial demersal fishing is banned along hundreds of kilometres of the WA coastline in an effort to recover fish species numbers.

item.title: Farmer restores and puts vintage harvester to work 95 years after its first season
item.description: While most farmers search for the newest technology to help with harvest, Leigh Baker has worked to bring a 95-year-old piece of equipment back to life.

item.title: US military attacks 'narco-trafficking' boats in international waters
item.description: US military forces have carried out strikes against three boats in international waters in the Pacific Ocean. Eight people are reported to have survived.

item.title: Lorin's father, satirist John Clarke, had a story to tell so she recorded their conversations
item.description: When Lorin Clarke asked her father, satirist John Clarke, if she could start recording their conversations, she thought it would just be for them. But when he tragically died aged 68, one year after the recordings began, Lorin felt his story belonged to more than just her.

item.title: France reportedly planning social media ban for under-15s
item.description: President Emmanual Macron's government will soon submit draft legislation banning children under 15 from using social media, according to French media.

item.title: Republican Lauren Boebert suggests Donald Trump veto could be Epstein files 'retaliation'
item.description: A month after Donald Trump's spectacular falling-out with MAGA firebrand Marjorie Taylor Greene, another Republican congresswoman publicly lashes out at the US president.

item.title: Pat Cummins, Josh Hazlewood and Tim David named in Australia's T20 World Cup squad despite injuries
item.description: Pat Cummins, Josh Hazlewood and Tim David are all included in Australia's 15-player squad for next month's men's Twenty20 World Cup in Sri Lanka and India.

item.title: Australian meat industry warns China's new beef tariff impact will be 'severe'
item.description: Meat Industry Council says it is "extremely disappointed" as China imposes a tariff on Australian beef imports that could cost $1 billion.

item.description: A 15-year-old boy has died in an e-bike crash on New Year's Eve, described by Tasmanian police as "tragic" and prompting a call for riders to comply with the law.

item.title: Amyl and the Sniffers singer Amy Taylor files lawsuit against photographer
item.description: Punk rock frontwoman of Amyl and the Sniffers Amy Taylor has filed a lawsuit against an American photographer alleging that photos taken for a magazine photo shoot are being sold against her wishes and without her permission.

item.title: SA Police arrest 72 people over New Year's Eve celebrations, including three teens over alleged stabbing
item.description: SA Police say 72 people were arrested and 10 were reported for offences overnight as the state rang in the new year.

item.description: Israel, suffering international isolation, has recognised a small territory desperate for international attention. Here's why it has caused an enormous stir.

item.title: In Dear Life, Brooke Satchwell connects with the recipients of her late fiance's organs
item.description: New Aussie drama Dear Life, from the creators of Upper Middle Bogan, looks at the strange and destructive ways people grieve — and how they live on.

item.title: Scepticism as Russia claims video proves Ukrainian drone attack on Putin residence
item.description: Moscow's allegation that Ukraine launched an attack on the Russian president's state residence is being dismissed as a ploy to derail peace talks.

item.description: Police are preparing a report for the coroner as authorities urge holiday-makers to follow safety advice.

item.title: Donald Trump says National Guard being removed from Chicago, LA and Portland
item.description: US President Donald Trump says his administration is removing the National Guard from Chicago, Los Angeles and Portland, but added federal forces will "come back" if crime rates go up.

item.title: Divers help free critically endangered grey nurse sharks from fishing gear
item.description: The Sea World Foundation teams up with divers to locate, catch and release tangled grey nurse sharks — often referred to as the "labradors of the sea", despite their toothy appearance.

item.title: Australian Winter Olympian Tess Coady fully fit for Milan-Cortina Games, after Beijing bronze medal
item.description: Fully-fit Australian snowboard medallist Tess Coady is looking forward to competing in the Winter Olympics next month in Italy after a torrid run with injury.

item.description: Aryna Sabalenka does not want her "Battle of the Sexes" clash with Nick Kyrgios to be the last and insists exhibitions have a vital role to play in tennis.

item.title: WA police searching for snorkeller missing off Ledge Point Beach, north of Perth
item.description: Authorities step up their search for a 32-year-old snorkeller missing since yesterday afternoon in the ocean off Ledge Point Beach, north of Perth, after he disappeared while diving for crayfish.

item.title: Walking with Moai: Unlocking the mysteries of Easter Island stone statues
item.description: A study using 11,600 aerial drone photos to map a mountainous quarry in 3D reveals more about how the island's famed stone sentinels were created and moved to their final resting places.

item.description: Hot weather has caused stressed trees to drop limbs, damaging property across South Australia and injuring one person so far this summer.

item.description: The days when councils decide if a second home or a granny flat are built on NSW's largest properties could be numbered.

item.description: Before his debut in 2011, Australia had never seen a cricketer like Usman Khawaja and, thanks to his work on and off the field, he'll be followed by plenty more.

item.title: Mother wallaby death sparks animal cruelty investigation in far north Queensland
item.description: Wildlife carers have lodged formal complaints with police and environment officials after stumbling across a scene involving a dead mother wallaby tied to a signpost.

item.title: Temporary power supply connected at NT town Jabiru after days of rolling blackouts
item.description: Faults with a power station's normal supply meant blackouts every two hours from New Year's Eve amid peak summer heat and humidity.

item.title: One man missing, another in hospital after collapse at Curragh mining complex in Central Queensland
item.description: One man is in hospital and another is missing following an incident at a Central Queensland coal mine.

item.title: Emergency services downgrade bushfire warning for Mundaring residents, Arson squad investigating
item.description: Police are investigating bushfires reported in the nearby suburbs of Boya and Koongamia, which firefighters bring under control on Saturday.

item.title: Donald Trump says US will 'come to their rescue' if Iran kills protesters
item.description: President Donald Trump says the United States is "locked and loaded" to respond if Iran kills protesters, prompting Tehran to warn that intervention would destabilise the region.

item.title: Kim Jong Un's daughter makes public visit to state mausoleum
item.description: The North Korean leader's daughter, reportedly named Kim Ju Ae, has been making increasingly prominent appearances in state media, fuelling speculation she may be in line to be the country's fourth-generation leader.

item.title: Volodymyr Zelenskyy names spy chief Kyrylo Budanov as new top aide, after ex-advisor quit over corruption probe
item.description: Ukraine's president has named Kyrylo Budanov, a legendary intelligence leader in the country, as the new head of his presidential office.

item.title: Albanese government can expect economic and political pressure in 2026
item.description: What are you watching in Australian politics in 2026? That's the question we put to the ABC's political journalists and columnists.

item.title: China-Taiwan-US triangle held together by assumptions and one dangerous lie
item.description: The US has no intention of abandoning Taiwan. But it also has no intention of binding itself to an automatic war commitment on a timeline it does not control.

item.title: ABC 50/50 quiz: This week we're testing your knowledge of Kylie Minogue, Greek gods and card games
item.description: Every question has only two options: one is right and the other is wrong. You have an even chance of guessing correctly each time.

item.title: Today in History, January 3: Steve Waugh secures a last-ball century to complete his perfect day
item.description: With one ball remaining on day two of the fifth Ashes Test in 2003, Steve Waugh stared down a century and his own cricketing mortality before securing one of the most famous centuries of his storied career.

item.title: Are reading goals helpful or performative? How to read more in the new year
item.description: While some people might find goal setting motivating — such as reading X number of books each year or pages each day — there is a risk of turning what is supposed to be a pleasurable activity into a chore.

item.title: Crans-Montana ski resort fire probe raises questions about sparklers, safety compliance at Le Constellation bar
item.description: The prevalence of sparklers at a Swiss ski resort bar where dozens of people died in a fire this week has been branded "irresponsible", as authorities probe potential compliance issues there.

item.title: World-first as Australian donates organs after self-administering assisted dying medication
item.description: An Australian woman is believed to have become the first person in the world to donate organs after self-administering oral voluntary assisted dying medication.

item.title: Red and yellow flags can be dangerously confusing. Is it time to change them?
item.description: Every summer, millions of Australians head to the beach and every year thousands are rescued by lifeguards or surf life savers, and even surfers or other bystanders.

item.title: Anastasia Golubeva set for 2026 Winter Olympics debut with Australia after citizenship change
item.description: Figure skater Anastasia Golubeva becomes an Australian citizen, just six weeks out from the Milano-Cortina Olympics.

item.title: The moon will loom extra large tonight — but it's not a supermoon
item.description: Stargazers will be treated with a supersized wolf moon for the first weekend of the year. Here's what to know.

item.title: Confronting the man who followed the ABC while reporting on Myanmar's elections
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: The parts of Myanmar the military junta doesn't want you to see
item.description: Myanmar's military is holding its first elections since overthrowing a democratically elected government in 2021. But as it aims to portray a sense of normality, signs of the junta's menacing presence are everywhere.

item.title: Flooded outback Queensland graziers to get $2m government package for fodder drops
item.description: Floodwaters remain in outback Queensland as graziers start to tally up livestock losses. Major flooding is possible in the north-west, with king tides forecast on the east coast.

item.title: From a Facebook appreciation group to viral TikTok reviews: Australia's love for bánh mì
item.description: A humble bánh mì appreciation group created by a Sydneysider has played a pivotal role in reinvigorating Australia's love for Vietnamese baguettes.

item.title: FBI says it thwarted ISIS-inspired New Year's Eve attack in North Carolina
item.description: The US Attorney for the Western District of North Carolina claims the 18-year-old suspect had planned to attack a grocery store and fast food restaurant in his hometown.

item.title: Mid North Coast brumby program rehomes 160 wild horses across Australia
item.description: About a third of the brumby population on the NSW Mid North Coast has been rehomed through a program designed to give wild horses a second chance as pets.

item.title: Naomi Osaka loses United Cup match to Maria Sakkari ahead of Australian Open
item.description: Just over two weeks from the season-opening major, former world number one Naomi Osaka reveals she is not at full health after contracting a viral illness over the Christmas period.

item.title: Housing program for pregnant homeless women faces high demand as expert calls for accurate data
item.description: While the exact number of pregnant women who are homeless in Victoria is unknown, experts say the outsized demand for specialty support services indicates more can be done.

item.title: Tesla loses title of bestselling EV company to BYD as sales drop
item.description: Tesla sales have declined for the second consecutive year, with Chinese rival BYD surpassing it as the world's largest electric vehicle maker.

item.title: Police hunt for offenders after shooting in Melbourne's inner north
item.description: Police are searching for offenders, who are believed to have driven past in a silver SUV and fired shots at a young man, before fleeing the scene.

item.title: Barbecue explosion prompts safety warning after Qld beautician's burns
item.description: Rachel Dear has a serious warning for anyone using a gas barbecue after she suffered significant face and body burns while cooking on Christmas Eve.

item.title: Coffee pods generate thousands of tonnes of waste in Australia. Here's what is being done about it
item.description: Between 10 and 20 per cent of the 3 million coffee pods Australians consume daily are actually recycled. Here's what's being done to change that.

item.title: Photographs of Men in Love exhibition reveals public glimpses of forbidden love
item.description: What started as a chance discovery of an old photo at a Dallas antique store has spawned a collection of more than 4,000 images of male couples, more than 100 of which are now on display in Canberra.

item.title: Helen Burnet has defected from the Greens but voters may still be wondering exactly why
item.description: Helen Burnet fronted the cameras on Friday to announce she was quitting the party she's been a member of for more than 20 years, but it's still not clear exactly why she's made the move.

item.title: WA's Pilbara region shares a human and shorebird FIFO population
item.description: Dozens of shorebird species flock to northern WA for summer during their global migration.

item.title: Searches called off for 14-year-old boy and man missing off Palm Beach and Coogee Beach in Sydney
item.description: Authorities suspend their searches for a 14-year-old boy and a man in his 20s who went missing off the Sydney coastline this week, following a horror week of drownings.

item.title: Middle Percy Island is a 'haven' for sailors, displaying scores of memorabilia from bygone days
item.description: Middle Percy Island is a rare gem where boaties can come ashore and wander through thousands of mementos left by travellers from across the globe.

item.title: Woman killed in suspected mountain lion attack on Colorado trail
item.description: The woman was found unresponsive by other hikers with injuries consistent with a mountain lion attack, authorities say.

item.title: Former Darwin councillor's ex-partner speaks out after guilty domestic violence verdict
item.description: Former Darwin councillor Paul Arnold was found guilty of domestic violence after a years-long court battle, with his ex-partner refusing to be scared into silence. She said the case was "stressful and deeply humiliating", but facing her abuser had been empowering.

item.title: Storm chaser captures rare red sprites across Kimberley sky
item.description: A storm chaser says he "screamed" when he captured an elusive natural phenomenon, known as red sprites, on video.

item.title: Red sprites erupt in the Kimberley sky.
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: NSW Police riot squad to carry long-arm firearms at Sydney Ashes series following Bondi attack
item.description: Officers will carry long-arm firearms as part of a bolstered police presence at the Ashes series in Sydney in the wake of the Bondi terror attack.

item.title: Premium beef producers expect to be the main casualty of China's new 55 per cent tariff
item.description: Australian cattle farmers producing wagyu and Angus beef are likely to be among the hardest hit by China's 55 per cent tariff on exports exceeding a 205,000-tonne quota.

item.title: Two separate echidna puggles unearthed during home renovations
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Wildlife carers warn people to watch out for puggle burrows this summer
item.description: With female echidnas seemingly creating burrows in random places at this time of the year, wildlife carers warn to keep an eye out for what might be disturbed while doing holiday work on your property.

item.title: Elder and MDAS ex-board member calls for government to take control of embattled Aboriginal organisation
item.description: A former director of an embattled Aboriginal organisation says the vote that removed her was fair and legitimate, and has asked the state government to intervene amid calls to re-run the vote.

item.title: Trailblazing US female jockey Diane Crump dies aged 77
item.description: Diane Crump, who in 1969 became the first woman to ride professionally in a horse race in the United States, dies at 77.

item.title: Local government inspector Tony Brown granted new powers to probe WA councils and 'improve accountability'
item.description: The new role of Western Australia local government inspector Tony Brown includes the ability to send in monitors — as well as legal and financial experts — to stamp out any early signs of trouble.

item.title: Rescue operations continue for missing worker at Central Queensland mine following roof collapse
item.description: A man remains unaccounted-for after a roof collapse at the Curragh mining complex in Central Queensland.

item.title: Driver arrested for allegedly speeding at 209km/h on Southern Expressway
item.description: Police say two 19-year-old drivers will face court for street racing along Adelaide's Southern Expressway, with one of the P-platers allegedly detected speeding at 209km/h.

item.title: Australia coy about Cameron Green's role in final Ashes Test against England at SCG
item.description: Steve Smith launches an impassioned defence of the out-of-form Cameron Green, but cannot guarantee the all-rounder's place in Australia's XI for the final Ashes Test.

item.title: Hunt for escaped red-whiskered bulbul that has SA's fruitgrowers worried
item.description: The sighting of a single red-whiskered bulbul in the wild might not seem like a big deal, but this invasive pest could put crops and the environment at risk.

item.title: Man charged with hit-and-run death of woman on Darwin's Bagot Road, one week after incident
item.description: Police arrest a 61-year-old man after a seven-day investigation involving CCTV, crime scene analysis, forensic examination and witness enquiries.

item.title: Spearfisher's death on South Coast fourth NSW drowning since New Year's Eve
item.description: The man was pulled unresponsive from the water at a remote beach south of Wollongong after he was tangled in a float line.

item.title: Yemen separatists announce plan to split country after 20 killed in Saudi-led strikes
item.description: A military official from the separatist group, which is backed by the United Arab Emirates, said that 20 fighters had been killed in air raids by the Saudi-backed coalition in the south of the country.

item.title: AI chatbot Grok under fire over complaints it let users undress minors in photos on X
item.description: The generative AI chatbot integrated with X is under international scrutiny after reports it was filling the social media platform with sexually explicit images of children and women.

item.title: Pakistan court sentences journalists to life in prison over links to 2023 protests after Imran Khan's arrest
item.description: Eight journalists and social media commentators are sentenced to life imprisonment in Pakistan after being convicted of terrorism-related offences linked to online activity in support of jailed former prime minister Imran Khan.

item.title: NSW Police investigating woman's death at Goulburn home
item.description: NSW Police launch an investigation after an unidentified woman was found dead in a home in Goulburn on Saturday morning.

item.title: DFAT supporting families after NSW Central Coast man killed and woman injured in Bali scooter crash
item.description: DFAT is supporting the families of a NSW Central Coast man killed and a woman injured in a scooter crash in Bali.

item.title: Man dies after ferocious fire at disability support home in south-west Sydney
item.description: A man dies and two people are hospitalised after a fire at a home in Sydney's south-west overnight.

item.title: Fight breaks out after crash on Monash Freeway in Melbourne's south-east
item.description: Police are investigating an altercation potentially involving edged weapons after a collision on the Monash Freeway in Melbourne's south-east.

item.title: Nick Kyrgios prepared to go through Australian Open qualifying if wildcard spot eludes him
item.description: Nick Kyrgios describes himself as a "chaotic mess, but an entertainer" as he prepares to return in Brisbane and awaits a call on his Australian Open status.

item.title: Donald Trump says US forces have captured Venezuelan leader Nicolas Maduro
item.description: US President Donald Trump says the US has captured Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, who earlier declared a national emergency and hit out at US "military aggression" after attacks in the capital, Caracas.

item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Helicopters stream into Caracas, the Venezuelan capital
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Venezuelan residents capture successive explosions
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Journalist in Caracas says Venezuelans still finding out Maduro has been captured
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.
